channel.title: Readings on Modern Research Methods:
channel.description: Recent content in Readings on Modern Research Methods:

item.description: Readings for class: [link] Syllabus for this class

Readings for class: [link] Karl Pearson The Grammar of Science, 939 (Walter Scott, 1892). [Section 5 only] [link] Brian A Nosek and Yoav Bar-Anan “Scientific Utopia: I. Opening Scientific Communication,” Psychological Inquiry 23, no. 3 (2012): 217–243. [pg. 217-219 required only]
Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 2: Intro to R. [link] Fun, cat-based introduction to R [OPTIONAL]
Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 3: Working with data.

Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 3: Working with data. [link] Hadley Wickham “Tidy Data,” Journal of Statistical Software 59, no. i10 (2014). [Optional]
Readings for class: [link] Jenny Bryan “Data Wrangling, Exploration, and Analysis with R (Stat 545)” (2019). Chapter 6: Introduction to dplyr.
Readings for class: [link] Jenny Bryan “Data Wrangling, Exploration, and Analysis with R (Stat 545)” (2019). Chapter 7: Single table dplyr functions.

Readings for class: [link] Kieran Healy Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton University Press, 2018). Chapter 3: Make a plot. [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 7: Data visualization with R (with Anna Khazenzon). [Optional, but encouraged!]

Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 4: Summarizing data. [link] Aran Lunzer and Amelia McNamara “Exploring Histograms, an Essay by Aran Lunzer and Amelia Mcnamara,” n.d.
Readings for class: [link] Kieran Healy Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton University Press, 2018). Chapter 4: Look at data.

Readings for class: [link] Jenny Bryan “Data Wrangling, Exploration, and Analysis with R (Stat 545)” (2019). Chapter 14: When one tibble is not enough. [link] Hadley Wickham Advanced R (Chapman; Hall/CRC, 2014). Chapter 9: Functionals. [Sections 9.1 - 9.2]
Readings for class:
Readings for class: [link] Jennifer Bryan “Excuse Me, Do You Have a Moment to Talk About Version Control?” The American Statistician 72, no. 1 (2018): 20–27.
Readings for class: [link] Learn Version Control with Git: A step-by-step course for the complete beginner
Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 12: Sampling.
Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 16: Hypothesis Testing.
Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 18: Quantifying effects and desiging studies. [18.1-18.2] Explore this app [Link]

Readings for class: [link] Russell A. Poldrack “Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century” (2019). Chapter 18: Quantifying effects and desiging studies. [18.3] [link] Jacob Cohen “A Power Primer,” Psychological Bulletin 112, no. 1 (1992): 155. A power prrimer. [Optional]
Readings for class: [link] Open Science Collaboration and others “Estimating the Reproducibility of Psychological Science,” Science 349, no. 6251 (2015): aac4716.
Readings for class: [link] John PA Ioannidis “Why Most Published Research Findings Are False,” PLoS Medicine 2, no. 8 (2005): e124.
Readings for class: [link] Trust in science would be improved by study pre-registration, The Guardian (2013). Readings for class: [link] Preregister everything, Michael C. Frank (2016)
Readings for class: [link] ???
Readings for class: [link] Matthew Salganik Bit by Bit: Social Research in the Digital Age (Princeton University Press, 2019). Chapter 2: Observing Behavior.
